/* Mesopotamian Arabic */ they speak it in the kurdish regions as well
/* Classical, Modern Standard, and spoken Arabic */
/* Examples */ phonemic, they already differ in more than that, the /ʕ/ never backs the open vowel in most accents and dialects
/* Romanization */ no need to transcribe full details for phonemes
/* Verbs */ the table is very redundant in that article, it's already at [[Arabic Grammar]]

Undid revision 449669162 by [[Special:Contributions/207.81.198.200|207.81.198.200]] ([[User talk:207.81.198.200|talk]]) rev vandalism
/* Classical, Modern Standard, and spoken Arabic */
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */ corrected the spelling of malayalam & added pustakam
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Consonants */ very irrelevant note; it doesn't matter what westerners are being taught or think of as being standard or more correct
/* Consonants */ what's the point of underlining d͡ʒ?
/* Consonants */ mostly non-Arabic; there are dozens of non-European origin
/* Verbs */ style; the one who wrote the case endings wrote them on the right most of the words (the opposite side of the word :D; hideous corrections
: ''For the vernaculars, see [[varieties of Arabic]]. For other languages containing the word "Arabic", see [[Arabic languages]].''
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */ rm unsourced insertion, + some fixes
official status, see [[Talk:Arabic language#Official status|talk page]]
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
Fix cite template param names, pp -> pages, p -> page, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (7822)
rm. DIN to match removal of ǧ
removed the official status, and moved it to [[Modern Standard Arabic]] because vernaculars have no official status
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */ completed with greek borrowings, and given some exemples of arabic words of semite and persian origin. language
Add link to on-line FSI course
/* Verbs */ Form V is nonexistent for k-t-b so indicate this
/* Maghrebi Arabic */ There is no Western Sahara Arabic.

/* Stress */ section on levels of pronunciation
/* Verbs */ add nominal forms to paradigm
/* Consonants */ note the versions that are considered "standard" according to linguistic sources
/* Stress */ rewrite stress using standard notation and underline instead of caps and doubled vowels
/* Mesopotamian Arabic */ There are no North-Mesopotamian-Arabic speakers in Northern Iran!
/* Literary Arabic */ rewrite section, add paradigm
[[Help:Reverting|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/Massalha|Massalha]] ([[User talk:Massalha|talk]]) to last version by Belovedfreak
/* Vowels */ the WHOLE SECTION is on MSA, that's why the section is titled "Literary Arabic" and it says things like "echo (to some extent) corresponding variations in the spoken dialects"
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Influence of Arabic on other languages */
/* Vowels */ because that word is often pronounced [sˤeːf] in many colloquial dialects, including Egyptian and is often monophthongized in MSA
/* Classical, Modern Standard, and spoken Arabic */ oops
/* Consonants */ [[Mehri language]] info is important because it exposes the ignorance :)
/* Classical, Modern Standard, and spoken Arabic */ Final -h indicates ''taa marbuuṭa''; this does not occur in verbs

/* Consonants */ clean this section up; remove comments about colloquial dialects or non-Arabic languages, because this section is about MSA; also I have a hard time believing that MSA in the Gulf really uses /j/; this is colloquial
/* Vowels */ clean up somewhat, note the front allophone of /aj/ tends to be more front than elsewhere
/* Vowels */ I'm not sure wha the purpose of this sentence is; we already say this section is only about MSA
/* Examples */ ''l-kitāba l-qadīmi'' cannot be correct, as the cases don't agree
/* Romanization */ too much details in an already long article
/* Romanization */ a, i, u is exactly the same for most other transliterations
/* Romanization */ foot-notes were at [[Romanization of Arabic]]
عربى the Egyptian, Sudanese way of writing the final ى
/* Consonants */ Although that sound exists in [[Mehri language]]
/* Literary Arabic */ another explanation on ج
revising some transliterations and transcriptions (as usual, wrong assumptions regarding ج phoneme)
/* Transliteration */ add table of different schemes, shortened from table at [[Arabic transliteration]]
/* Dialects and descendants */ add example sentences
/* Sounds */ rewrite, adding desc. of spoken dialects and continuing to more clearly separate literary from colloquial spoken
/* Sounds */ rewrite, more clearly separate literary from colloquial spoken
/* Classical, Modern Standard, and spoken Arabic */ differences between Meccan Koran Arabic and the language of the Koran
/* Classical, Modern Standard, and spoken Arabic */ rewrite para on vocab
/* Classical, Modern Standard, and spoken Arabic */ rewrite
/* Classical, Modern Standard, and spoken Arabic */ delete a sentence that makes very little sense and does not add to the content

/* Grammar */ The word "to lose (one's toothbrush, but also a football match, a wager, etc.)" has only one o. However, the word "to loosen" (one's tie, one's shoelaces, restrictions on behaviour) has two <o>s - did you mean the latter word?
